text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

BRIAN KENNY: In 1904,
journalist Upton Sinclair

published a
groundbreaking novel that

exposed the harsh working
conditions in Chicago's
meatpacking industry.

He intended his book The
Jungle to be a rallying

cry for social justice
for the workers,

but what really got
readers worked up

was his unflinching depiction
of the unsanitary conditions
in which the meat was processed.

After all, that meat was going
to end up on their table.

Sinclair famously quipped, I
aimed for the public's heart

and accidentally hit
it in the stomach.

The public outcry sparked
by The Jungle led directly

to the establishment of
the Meat Inspection Act

which authorized the
secretary of agriculture

to inspect and condemn
any meat product

found unfit for
human consumption.

It was the first wave of
food and drug regulations

that swept over the US
in the 20th century,

spawning a vast array
of agencies and legions

of inspectors all
with the same goal,

to keep consumers
safe from harm.

Yet, still, according to the
Food and Drug Administration,

about 48 million
people, that's 1 in 6,

are sickened by foodborne
illness each year,

and 3,000 die, raising the
question, just how effective
is food industry regulation?

Today, we'll hear from
Professor Ray Goldberg

about his case entitled
"Wegmans and Listeria:

Developing a Proactive Food
Safety System for Produce."

I'm your host Brian Kenny, and
you're listening to Cold Call.

SPEAKER 2: So we are all
sitting there in the classroom.
SPEAKER 3: Professor walks in.

SPEAKER 4: And they look up,
and you know what's coming.

SPEAKER 5: Oh, the
dreaded cold call.

SPEAKER 6: Ray Goldberg joined
the faculty of Harvard Business

School in 1955, and
he's been investigating

the functioning of the global
agribusiness system ever since.

The agribusiness
program he developed,

in 1955, continues to
bring business leaders

and policymakers from around
the world together each year.

And throughout his
tenure, Ray has

written over 100
articles and 24 books

on the business of agriculture,
including his very latest, Food

Citizenship: Food
System Advocates
in an Era of Distrust.

Ray, thanks for
joining me today.

RAY GOLDBERG: Thank
you for having me.

BRIAN KENNY: So did you
coined the term agribusiness?

RAY GOLDBERG: I did
together with John Davis.

The two of us coined
the word together.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

RAY GOLDBERG: He was
the assistant secretary

of agriculture under Eisenhower,
and he became the first head
of the agribusiness program.

BRIAN KENNY: OK, and that
terms lives on today,

and what you started so long
ago continues to thrive probably

because of a lot of
the reasons that we're

going to discuss in this
case today about Wegmans.
I confess, I'm a fan of Wegmans.

They opened one up near
where I live not long ago,

and they've really
done a great job

in changing the way people
think about grocery shopping.

It'll be interesting
for people to hear

the context of this case and
how Wegmans is thinking about it

and what the issues are more
broadly around food safety.

Maybe I'll ask you to start just
the way we normally do here.

Can you tell us,
in this case, who's

the protagonist, and
what's on his mind?

RAY GOLDBERG: Well,
the protagonist here

is Danny Wegman and his head
of produce, David Corsi.

They were concerned as to
whether the requirements

of the FDA, the
EPA, and the USDA

in terms of how to manage
a disease, E. coli,

should be a zero
tolerance or not.

Everybody else in the world
gives them a little leeway

that enables them
to continue to ship,

even if two or three
items are shown
to actually have listeria.

And the case was
concerning a company

that supplied produce
both in the United States
and to Australia.

The Australian company
saw these three items

and decided they
were going to use it.

But they at the same
time called Wegmans

to see if they had
any problems with that

and also called the
supplier of that product

to see if he could find
the source of that listeria
in his company.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

RAY GOLDBERG: And
that led to this case.

BRIAN KENNY: This is not
your first case on Wegmans.

You've actually been writing
about Wegmans for a while.

RAY GOLDBERG: I have
for a very long while,

because they are the
most admired supermarket
in our country.

The students in my
class, when they come in,

and I'm looking at the
schedule, I'll say to them,

has anybody ever worked
for Wegmans, when
we're having the Wegmans case.

And two or three hands
will show up, and I said,
what do you think of Wegmans?
I'm in love with Wegmans.
[LAUGHING]

RAY GOLDBERG: And then
they proceed to tell me
what a wonderful company it is.

But they do so much for their
community, for the employees,

for the education
of their community,

for the health of
their community

that it's hard for anyone to
imagine one firm doing that.

And when Danny Wegman
comes to class,

he's the only visitor who
stands at the front door

of the classroom and
shakes everybody's hand
as they walk into the room.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

That says something right
there, and Danny's actually

featured in one of the
chapters in your new book.

You get a little sense for
what he's like as a leader too.

RAY GOLDBERG: Well, he
basically talks about the fact

that he asked his father
about the interview I
was going to have with him.

And the father said, well, what
are you going to talk about?

And I said, well, he wants me
to talk about our relationship
with the community.

He said, well, without a
relationship in the community,
we shouldn't be in business.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.
Yeah, so true.

So why don't we get right
to the core of the matter

here in the case is
this listeria issue.

How prevalent is foodborne
illness writ large?

RAY GOLDBERG: Well,
it's very prevalent.

You started this
conversation yourself

with 46 million
people, and one 1

of 6 people being affected by
some kind of adverse condition
of that food.

You say 3,000 people die every
year, and 260 of those 3,000
die from listeria.
BRIAN KENNY: Mm-hm.

The case goes on to cite some
examples of foodborne illness
outbreaks in the US.

We're coming very recently
on the heels of the Romaine

lettuce issue in the US which
has now occurred I think twice
in the last few months.

Clearly, these are
things that are almost

ripped from the
headlines, but there

have been some very high
visibility ones over the year.

Do you want to describe
a couple of those?

RAY GOLDBERG: Well, I can
describe the Romaine lettuce

one, because I talked to the
produce manager this morning,

and he tells me the cost to
the industry was $100 million.
BRIAN KENNY: Wow.

RAY GOLDBERG: The problem
is that Romaine lettuce

itself, when cold
temperatures occur,

begin to blister which make them
more susceptible to listeria.

When they tried to find the
location of that listeria,

it came from the dairy
herd about 2,000 feet away

from where that
lettuce was grown.

Well, we have a rule that
1,200 feet is far enough,

but they actually
found listeria a mile

away from where the
lettuce was concerned.

So he feels very strongly that
they have to change the rules.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.
Yeah.

Listeria, we know
it's very serious.

Obviously, it makes
people very sick.

It can be deadly, but
is there a safe level?

[INAUDIBLE] one of the
questions in the case comes up,

is zero tolerance
the right policy,

or is there a safe level
that people can consume?

RAY GOLDBERG: Well, we are the
only country in the world that
has zero tolerance.

The rest of the world
is more lenient,

but since this case was
written, our government

has been more
lenient in the sense

that, if something
is discovered,

they will let you go
back to your plant.

And if you can prove that you
have no more listeria there,
then they will let you continue.

The gentleman in
this particular case

couldn't find the
source of listeria,
but it was still there.
He couldn't find it.

He basically had to create
a whole new company.

His company is now the model for
best practices for the country.

So he decided that, once and
for all, he was going all out,
and he did it.

BRIAN KENNY: Which
gets to another issue

that the case raises which
is the plethora of government

agencies that have sprung up
all in service to food safety.

Has the industry
done well enough
trying to regulate itself?

What are the some of the
things that the industry has
tried to do?

RAY GOLDBERG: Well, the
industry has actually,

under Danny Wegmans
leadership-- he

was the person in
charge of food safety,

of the food marketing
institute that really
looked at the whole industry.

And he got several
members of the industry

to sit down and create new
rules with the FDA, the EPA,

the USDA, and CDC,
all of them saying,
we have to have better rules.

Produce, as you
know in the case,

is the most valuable
part of a supermarket

but also the most
susceptible to problems.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

In an age where
people are looking

for more and more
organic things,

there's a lot of people
that are suspect of any

of these kinds of
processing approaches.

RAY GOLDBERG: Well,
and we want them

to eat more fruits and
vegetables, because they'll
be healthier if they do.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

RAY GOLDBERG: So consequently,
I think that the more stringent

the rules are, the better
for everybody, including

the industry, and I think
the industry finally
agrees to that.

BRIAN KENNY: You mentioned that
the US has more stringent rules
than other parts of the world.

How have other countries
dealt with this?

RAY GOLDBERG: Other countries
have been a little more lenient

in terms of the
fact that listeria

may show up in shipments, may
get contaminated along the way,

and may not really reflect
the purity of the product.

But the company in Australia,
when they heard of the problem

and then they called
Wegmans, and when

Wegmans called the other
company that had the problem,

and the company couldn't
find the problem,

they decided not to use
the shipment either.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

RAY GOLDBERG: So I
think every country

is very sensitive to it, and
the FDA, the EPA, the USDA

all work closely with their
counterparts around the world.

And many of the people
in those organizations

have helped other countries
create their own food safety
organizations.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.
What do you find--

I'm thinking in China,
they had issues with dairy
not too long ago.

I don't know if
those issues persist.

But when you get into countries
where the government really

has an iron-fisted
control over industry,

do you think that they're
taking the same level of concern
for consumers?
RAY GOLDBERG: No.

They don't, unfortunately,
but what's happened

is that the consumer
in China got so upset

with the melamine problem of
adulterating the milk that they
didn't buy local milk.
They bought foreign milk.

And so consequently,
the market has

forced these other governments
to become more stringent.

In fact, what happened is
that the government of China,

working with the government
of the United States,

created a Dairy Farm Institute
under the leadership of Nestle

and Land O'Lakes in this country
and other dairy companies
around the world.

And I did a case study on that
to show how all of these people

got together to correct the
problem that was taking place.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

RAY GOLDBERG: But we not only
have a problem of disease,
we have adulteration.

You remember the horse
meat scandal that we had.

Again, a new company
was created that

uses DNA that identified
the horse meat,

and that company is now
working in the United States
and around the world.

And I remember talking to
people at Chateau Lafite

about how do you know that
your wine is pure and so forth?
He said, Ray, we don't.

I said, well, can you
give me an example?

He said, China is
a perfect example.

More Chateau Lafite is sold
than we have ever shipped.
BRIAN KENNY: Wow.

RAY GOLDBERG: So
it's a tough problem.

It's not just
adulteration and safety.
It's terrible.

BRIAN KENNY: Yeah, and
this gets a little bit

to your book, the
topic of your book,

Food System Advocates
in an Era of Distrust.

Can you talk a little bit
about the big ideas coming out
of your book?

RAY GOLDBERG: Well, the big
ideas coming out of the book

are twofold, I would say,
that the kind of men and women

in the industry have
changed from commodity

handlers and bargaining
as to how cheap they

can buy something or
how expensive they

can make something
to finally realizing
that they have to be trusted.

And because they
have to be trusted,

they have to start working
together to create that trust.

In addition to
that, they realize

that the private, public,
and not-for-profit sector
really need to work together.

And that's why I
tried to write a book

to give people an inkling
of the kind of men and women

in this industry who really
are the change-makers

and who really are changing
it to a consumer-oriented,

health-oriented,
environmentally-oriented,

economic development-oriented
industry.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

So let's go back to
the Wegmans case then.
You've discussed this in class.

You mentioned Danny has
come to class before.
RAY GOLDBERG: Yeah.

Danny came to class, and the
head of the produce department

came to class, the
two of them together.

BRIAN KENNY: So just
given the differences

in the way countries
approach this,

I'm curious as to how the
class discussion unfolds,

because I would imagine there's
a lot of different perspectives
in that room.

RAY GOLDBERG: There are a lot
of different perspectives,

but one thing about
this younger generation,

at least at the
Harvard Business School

and some of the
other schools I've

had the privilege
of teaching at,

these people recognize the
importance of the food system

more so than any
generation I ever taught.

They also look at the food
system as the most important

system to try to overcome
poverty and malnutrition
around the world.

They also realize
it's a class issue,

that people who are better
educated, have more resources,

know more about food and
relating it to health.

They also recognize that
the medical schools finally

look at nutrition being more
important than popping pills.

So this case goes way
beyond just food safety.

It really looks
at how do you work

with the community and
the rest of the world

so that the food system
becomes the change-maker
and improves that world?

So that's why I was
anxious to write the book,

and we're very
fortunate at Harvard

to get men and women to come
here and talk to our students

and let us write
cases about them.

BRIAN KENNY: Ray, thank
you for joining me today.

RAY GOLDBERG: It's
a real privilege

to talk about a subject that
I've loved my whole life.
BRIAN KENNY: Thanks again.
RAY GOLDBERG: My pleasure.

BRIAN KENNY: If you
enjoy Cold Call,

you should check out HBS Sky
Deck, a podcast series that

features interviews
with HBS alumni

from across the
world of business,

I'm Brian Kenny,
